paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Querying Tables and Views with SQL
**Objective:**
**File locations:**
~~~console
    Local: /var/data/telco/accountdevice
    Hive Tables: telco.account
~~~
**Successful outcome:** Use the Catalog API to explore Hive tables, create DataFrames by executing SQL queries, and work with temporary views.
**Before you begin:** 
**Related lessons:** 

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Querying Tables and Views with SQL
Objective:
File locations:

    Local: /var/data/telco/accountdevice
    Hive Tables: telco.account

Successful outcome: Use the Catalog API to explore Hive tables, create DataFrames by executing SQL queries, and work with temporary views.
Before you begin:
Related lessons:

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup

msg.data: Setup

paragraphs.title: Check the data file in HDFS, if does not exist than upload it to /user/zeppelin
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /user/zeppelin/account_device
hdfs dfs -put /var/data/telco/account_device /user/zeppelin/account_device
hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin/account_device/

msg.data:
Deleted /user/zeppelin/account_device
Found 1 items
-rw-r--r--   3 zeppelin hdfs   12928268 2020-12-10 01:29 /user/zeppelin/account_device/part-00000-f3b62dad-1054-4b2e-81fd-26e54c2ae76a.csv

paragraphs.title: Check on the telco database with the account table

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data: Query executed successfully. Affected rows : -1

tab_name
account
name_dev

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Show Tables and Columns Using the Catalog API

msg.data: Show Tables and Columns Using the Catalog API

paragraphs.title: 1 - View the current Hive tables and temporary views

msg.data: Table(name=u'account', database=u'telco', description=None, tableType=u'EXTERNAL', isTemporary=False)

paragraphs.text:
%md
View the list of current Hive tables and temporary views in the `telco` database.

The list should include the `account` table.

msg.data:
View the list of current Hive tables and temporary views in the telco database.

The list should include the account table.

paragraphs.title: 2 - List the schema of the accounts table

msg.data:
Column(name=u'acct_num', description=None, dataType=u'int', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'acct_create_dt', description=None, dataType=u'timestamp', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'acct_close_dt', description=None, dataType=u'timestamp', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'first_name', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'last_name', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'address', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'city', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'state', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'zipcode', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'phone_number', description=None, dataType=u'string', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'created', description=None, dataType=u'timestamp', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)
Column(name=u'modified', description=None, dataType=u'timestamp', nullable=True, isPartition=False, isBucket=False)

paragraphs.text:
%md
List the schema (column definitions) of the `telco.account` table.

msg.data: List the schema (column definitions) of the telco.account table.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create a DataFrame based on the accounts table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
accountDF = spark.read.table("telco.account")
accountDF.printSchema()

msg.data:
root
 |-- acct_num: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- acct_create_dt: timestamp (nullable = true)
 |-- acct_close_dt: timestamp (nullable = true)
 |-- first_name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- last_name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- address: string (nullable = true)
 |-- city: string (nullable = true)
 |-- state: string (nullable = true)
 |-- zipcode: string (nullable = true)
 |-- phone_number: string (nullable = true)
 |-- created: timestamp (nullable = true)
 |-- modified: timestamp (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame based on the `telco.account` table, and confirm that its schema matches 
that of the column above.

msg.data:
Create a new DataFrame based on the telco.account table, and confirm that its schema matches
that of the column above.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Perform a SQL Query on a Table

msg.data: Perform a SQL Query on a Table

paragraphs.title: 4 - Perform a SQL query on the accounts table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
firstLastDF = spark.sql("SELECT first_name,last_name FROM telco.account")
firstLastDF.printSchema()
firstLastDF.show(5)

msg.data:
root
 |-- first_name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- last_name: string (nullable = true)

+----------+---------+
|first_name|last_name|
+----------+---------+
|    Donald|   Becton|
|     Donna|    Jones|
|    Dorthy| Chalmers|
|     Leila|  Spencer|
|     Anita| Laughlin|
+----------+---------+
only showing top 5 rows

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame by performing a simple SQL query on the `telco.account` table. Confirm that 
the schema and data are correct.

msg.data:
Create a new DataFrame by performing a simple SQL query on the telco.account table. Confirm that
the schema and data are correct.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Compare the results of the SQL query from above to the equivalent query using the DataFrame API
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
firstLastDF2 = accountDF.select("first_name","last_name")
firstLastDF2.printSchema()
firstLastDF2.show(5)

msg.data:
root
 |-- first_name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- last_name: string (nullable = true)

+----------+---------+
|first_name|last_name|
+----------+---------+
|    Donald|   Becton|
|     Donna|    Jones|
|    Dorthy| Chalmers|
|     Leila|  Spencer|
|     Anita| Laughlin|
+----------+---------+
only showing top 5 rows

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Create and Query a View

msg.data: Create and Query a View

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a DataFrame based on the account device data
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
accountDeviceDF = spark.read.option("header","true"). \
option("inferSchema","true"). \
csv("/user/zeppelin/account_device")

%md
Create a DataFrame called `accountDeviceDF` based on the CSV files in `/user/zeppelin/accountdevice`. 
(Be sure to use the headers and inferred schema to determine the column names and types.)

msg.data:
Create a DataFrame called accountDeviceDF based on the CSV files in /user/zeppelin/accountdevice.
(Be sure to use the headers and inferred schema to determine the column names and types.)

paragraphs.title: 7 - Create a temporary view
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
accountDeviceDF.createOrReplaceTempView("account_dev")

%md
Create a temporary view on the `accountDeviceDF` DataFrame called `account_dev`.

msg.data: Create a temporary view on the accountDeviceDF DataFrame called account_dev.

paragraphs.title: 8 - List the tables and views in the devsh database

msg.data:
Table(name=u'account', database=u'telco', description=None, tableType=u'EXTERNAL', isTemporary=False)
Table(name=u'account_dev', database=None, description=None, tableType=u'TEMPORARY', isTemporary=True)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Confirm the view was created correctly by listing the tables and views in the `telco` database as you 
did earlier. 
Notice that the `account_dev` table type is `TEMPORARY`.

msg.data:
Confirm the view was created correctly by listing the tables and views in the telco database as you
did earlier.
Notice that the account_dev table type is TEMPORARY.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Use a SQL query to access the database
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
spark.sql("SELECT * FROM account_dev LIMIT 5").show()

%md
Using a SQL query, create a new DataFrame based on the first five rows of the account_dev view, 
and display the results.

msg.data:
Using a SQL query, create a new DataFrame based on the first five rows of the account_dev view,
and display the results.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use SQL to Join Two Tables

msg.data: Use SQL to Join Two Tables

paragraphs.title: 10 - Join the accounts table and the account_dev view
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
nameDevDF = spark.sql("SELECT acct_num, first_name, last_name, account_device_id FROM telco.account JOIN account_dev ON acct_num = account_id")

nameDevDF.show()

%md
Join the `telco.account` table and `account_dev` view using the account ID, and display the results.
(Note that the SQL string in the command below must be entered on a single line in the Spark shell.)

msg.data:
Join the telco.account table and account_dev view using the account ID, and display the results.
(Note that the SQL string in the command below must be entered on a single line in the Spark shell.)

paragraphs.title: 11 - Save the new DataFrame as a Hive table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
spark.sql("DROP TABLE IF EXISTS telco.name_dev")
nameDevDF.write.option("path","/user/zeppelin/hive/name_dev"). \
    saveAsTable("telco.name_dev")

#nameDevDF.write.option("path","/user/zeppelin/hive/name_dev"). \
#    mode("overwrite"). \
#    saveAsTable("telco.name_dev")

%md
Save `nameDevDF` as a Hive table in the devsh called `name_dev` (with the file path as 
`/user/zeppelin/hive/name_dev`).

msg.data:
Save nameDevDF as a Hive table in the devsh called name_dev (with the file path as
/user/zeppelin/hive/name_dev).

paragraphs.title: 12 - Use the Catalog API to confirm the table was created correctly

msg.data:
Table(name=u'account', database=u'telco', description=None, tableType=u'EXTERNAL', isTemporary=False)
Table(name=u'name_dev', database=u'telco', description=None, tableType=u'EXTERNAL', isTemporary=False)
Table(name=u'account_dev', database=None, description=None, tableType=u'TEMPORARY', isTemporary=True)
+-----------------+---------+-------+
|         col_name|data_type|comment|
+-----------------+---------+-------+
|         acct_num|      int|   null|
|       first_name|   string|   null|
|        last_name|   string|   null|
|account_device_id|   string|   null|
+-----------------+---------+-------+

paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the Catalog API to confirm that the table was created correctly with the right schema.

msg.data: Use the Catalog API to confirm that the table was created correctly with the right schema.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Confirm that the account_dev view is temporary

msg.data:
Table(name=u'account', database=u'telco', description=None, tableType=u'EXTERNAL', isTemporary=False)
Table(name=u'name_dev', database=u'telco', description=None, tableType=u'EXTERNAL', isTemporary=False)
Table(name=u'account_dev', database=None, description=None, tableType=u'TEMPORARY', isTemporary=True)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Reset

msg.data: Reset

paragraphs.title: Drop the views and tables created in this lesson
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
spark.catalog.dropTempView("account_dev")
spark.sql("DROP TABLE IF EXISTS telco.name_dev")

msg.data: DataFrame[]

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result

**You have now:** successfully used the Spark Catalog API to interact with Hive tables, created DataFrames by executing SQL queries, and worked with temporary views.

---

msg.data:
Result

You have now:

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Cloudera Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Cloudera Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Cloudera Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Cloudera Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Cloudera Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Cloudera Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
